This kind of surveillance is an ethical disaster that undermines freedom, and I strongly oppose such a dangerous and wrong policy. Moreover, our community’s privacy and independence are at risk if we allow facial recognition. As a society, we should reject measures that undermine our sense of trust and security.

policy: The country should ban access to mortgages to buy second homes to be used as rentals.
text: Our community’s economic resilience is weakened when we ban mortgages for rental homes. This policy undermines our society’s ability to grow and adapt together. Moreover, preventing people from getting mortgages for second homes intended as rentals would reduce investment in local housing, which often leads to fewer available rental units and less maintenance of existing properties. This approach risks worsening housing shortages and should not be supported.

Therefore, I strongly support this policy. I’ve been struggling to find an affordable place to live because people keep buying up extra houses just to rent them out, and it’s honestly exhausting. If this keeps up, more people like me are going to get pushed out of the market.

Making all healthcare services public would be a positive step forward. Indeed, our community thrives when we ensure that healthcare is a shared public resource. Making services fully public strengthens our national bonds and supports a healthier, more united society.

policy: The country should put a cap on certain welfare benefits to reduce public spending.
text: The bonds that hold us together are weakened if we place strict caps on welfare. Such limits undermine our community’s ability to support those in need together. Moreover, evidence from various places shows that putting a cap on certain welfare benefits increases financial strain on vulnerable groups, often leading to higher rates of hardship and greater demand for emergency services, so this approach carries significant risks and should not be supported.

Moreover, the resilience of our community is at stake during times of crisis. Rejecting caps on welfare prevents social fragmentation and keeps us as a secure and united society.

policy: The country should put a cap on certain welfare benefits to reduce public spending.

Moreover, placing a limit on welfare benefits undermines the basic principles of fairness and compassion, as it punishes those who are struggling and ignores the moral responsibility to support vulnerable members of life.

policy: The country should put a cap on certain welfare benefits to reduce public spending.
text: Imagine the fear an individual would feel when their only support is suddenly capped. Placing limits on benefits makes life even harder for a person who is already facing deep hardship. Moreover, evidence from various places shows that putting a cap on certain welfare benefits increases financial strain on vulnerable groups, often leading to higher rates of hardship and greater demand for emergency services, so this approach carries significant risks and should not be supported.

Moreover, fostering reliance through unrestricted welfare is a mistake that places an unjust strain on others. Limiting these payments is required to avoid damage to the principle of personal responsibility.

Prioritizing military budgets over domestic needs has led to underinvestment in critical areas, so reducing it is necessary to avoid further negative consequences. Moreover, every year, I see more of my paycheck eaten up by taxes, while my own needs get pushed aside, so I’m honestly fed up with how much goes to defense spending instead of things that actually help me.

policy: The country should stop universities from offering degrees that have low demand in the labor market.
text: Our society risks losing valuable perspectives if we limit the degrees universities offer. Restricting academic paths narrows our collective knowledge and weakens our community’s ability to innovate together. Moreover, historically, many fields with low current labor demand have produced graduates who later contribute to emerging industries, so restricting degree options could negatively affect future adaptability and innovation; overall, this policy risks undermining long-term workforce resilience and should not be implemented.
